title: 103_hr5024
content: The Act is titled the "National Training Center for Minority Museum, Archives, and Historic Preservation Professionals Act." It includes findings and purposes for the establishment of the center. The National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center was established in 1980 in Wilberforce, Ohio with the intent of being a joint Federal-State project, but the State of Ohio has taken on almost exclusive financial responsibility for its construction and development. The National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center in Ohio lacks minority representation in museum professionals and needs federal funds for a training center. Public Law 101-628 mandates the preservation of the Underground Railroad story. The National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center in Ohio requires federal funds for a training center to preserve and commemorate the Underground Railroad story. The National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center in Ohio requires federal funds for a training center to preserve and commemorate the Underground Railroad story. Definitions in the Act include the Board of Governors, Director, and Museum. The Act also covers the construction and maintenance of the National Training Center. The Director will construct a National Training Center at the Museum in collaboration with Ohio to train professionals for museums, archives, and preservation offices. The Board of Governors will oversee the operation, maintenance, and provide technical assistance to the Museum. Additionally, there will be provisions for minority museum professional studies. The Secretary of Education will contract with a consortium of higher education institutions to implement a graduate degree program for minorities in museum, archives, and historic preservation studies at the Museum. They will also offer seminars and workshops in collaboration with professional organizations like the African American Museums Association. Scholarships and loans will be provided for students and professionals in these studies. The Secretary of Education and the Director can establish a Board of Governors for the National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center in Ohio. The Board must meet specific requirements, including four members appointed by the Governor of Ohio, including university presidents and the Director of the Ohio Historical Society. The Board of Governors for the National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center in Ohio consists of members appointed by the Governor, Secretary, and Director, with diverse backgrounds and a commitment to advancing knowledge of African American and minority history. Members serve three-year terms and may be reappointed. The Board of Governors for the National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center in Ohio consists of members appointed by the Governor, Secretary, and Director, with staggered three-year terms. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without compensation unless specified. The Board of Governors appointed for the National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center in Ohio serve without pay, but receive expenses for their duties. They elect a chairperson and meet as needed. The Board of Governors for the National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center in Ohio meet at least twice a year, with a majority constituting a quorum for conducting business. The chairperson may accept voluntary services from board members. The National Center for the Study of Afro-American History and Culture Act will be repealed 30 days after the enactment of this Act. The duties, authorities, and responsibilities of the Board of Governors of the Museum are outlined in Section 7. The Board of Governors established for the Museum has duties including recommending budgets, managing collections, and acquiring artifacts for the Museum. The Board of Governors for the Museum has the authority to establish policies for collections, programming, education, exhibitions, and research related to African American history. They also have the authority to provide for restoration, preservation, and maintenance of collections, as well as solicit funds and determine their use. The Board of Governors for the Museum has the authority to establish policies for collections, programming, education, exhibitions, and research related to African American history. They can approve expenditures from the endowment for any purpose of the Museum, consult with the Director, establish programs with other minority museums, and support educational efforts regarding minority life, art, history, and culture. The Board of Governors for the Museum has the authority to develop cooperative programs, manage collections, train professionals, and create research and internship opportunities. They are also responsible for adopting bylaws and reporting annually to Congress and the Ohio legislature on minority American objects and artifacts. Authorization of appropriations for the Museum includes $2,000,000 for planning and design in 1996, $10,000,000 for construction in 1997 and 1998, $1,000,000 for operation and maintenance, $25,000 annually for the Board of Governors, and funding for Minority Museum Professional Studies.
